testimony:
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Chairman, I would like to call the matter of Mlungisi Nyembezi, Luzuko Sidney Mpiyakhe, Solomzi Theo Nomatshizole, Luyanda Ntikinca.
	Chairperson, I would like the legal representatives involved in this matter to introduce themselves and read their names into the record.  My name Chairperson is Zuko Mapoma, the leader of evidence for the Committee.
Honourable Chair, my name is Notununu N.M.,  represent the four applicants in this matter sir.
Mr Chairman, and Honourable members of the Panel, I represent the Mbhele family.  My name is Adv A.R. Brink, I am instructed by the Legal Aid Board.
Are we going to conduct this hearing in a similar fashion as to yesterday's one?

Honourable Chair, we have had some pretrial conference of some kind between MR BRINK and Mr Mapoma and by so doing, we wanted to check whether there could be some ways of shortening the proceedings.
	What we have actually agreed on Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel was that we are going to call the deponent in the main affidavit, that is Nyembezi and thereafter also call Luyanda Ntikinca, who has apparently been implicated as a person from whom two of the firearms were found.
	Apparently MR BRINK seemed to be satisfied with that, but he did indicate that he was not in fact merits to that, but so far, this is the position.
What would be the point in calling Mr Ntikinca?

As already indicated Honourable Chair, that was on the insistence of MR BRINK for the Mbhele family.  He said there are some things he possibly want to ask from him.  I don't know the type of things.  Perhaps he is the person who can better be in a position to answer that question.
	The other thing, Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel, I wish to mention is that in that conference we had also eliminated some of the things, for instance as from paragraph 1 of the affidavit of Nyembezi which is on page 13, Honourable Chair and Honourable members of our case, our application, page 13, that is the affidavit of Mlungisi Nyembezi, of our affidavits.
	From paragraph 1 right up to paragraph 12, from paragraph 1 right up to paragraph 12, we had agreed between the three of us that all those facts therein are admitted and as such, MR BRINK apparently is disputing the rest of the paragraphs in the main affidavit of Mr Nyembezi and those are then the issues on which we are going to call the evidence, from paragraph 13 Honourable Chair, right up to the end apparently.
	Right up to the last paragraph, that is paragraph 31.  Thank you Honourable Chair.
Mr Brink, the calling of the other applicant, can we leave that in abeyance and then you can decide or we can decide at a later stage what to do?

Thank you Honourable Chair.  Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel, this is an application in terms of Section 18 of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act, 34 of 1995.
	The applicants herein Honourable Chair and Honourable members are as mentioned by Mr Mapoma, the Officer leading evidence.  As already indicated Honourable Chair, there are some issues where parties have agreed.
	I now propose to call the evidence of the main deponent, that is Mlungisi Nyembezi herein.

Mr Nyembezi, you are appearing before this Commission today and the purpose of coming here are for you to tell the Honourable Chair and Honourable Panel and all the members of the public herein, about the taking of two policemen at Bongweni police station in 1993, who were subsequently found dead during the night or in the morning.
	Do you promise that you are in fact going to tell the whole story to the Honourable Chair and the Honourable members of the Panel?

Now, you also understand Mr Nyembezi, that the members, the family members of the deceased could be amongst us here.  Will you then avail them the opportunity of really making them know what happened to their beloved ones by telling the whole truth and the whole story?
Now, it is common cause Mr Nyembezi, that you were a member of what is known or was known as Self Defence Units, having been trained by MK cadres, is that the position?
Now, it is also common cause Mr Nyembezi, that some of your duties as Self Defence Units, were to in fact protect the communities against the atrocities committed by the enemy, is that so?

Now, we start with the paragraph 10, Honourable Chair and Honourable members, do you recall an incident in 1993 when the innocent children sleeping in a house in Northcrest, were brutally massacred by the then South African Defence Force?
Now, you also recall or attended the burial of those children?
Were you with your co-applicants, that is the three seated behind us, at the time when you attended the funeral?
Yes, that is true, we were with our comrades.
Now, can you describe the funeral itself, the burial ceremony, how was it?  Was it a moving thing, was it a joyous thing, how was the funeral itself?
Even more important, you say you attended this funeral, did it affect you in any way?
Yes sir, it is the sadness, the immense grief that touched me deeply.
You were touched by the sadness and the immense grief as you say?
Yes sir, it was tragic that students so young could be so brutally attacked.  The parents were in an unbearable kind of grief, we were also in absolute pain.

Now, Mr Nyembezi, I understand that there were claims which were made by the then President De Klerk, when he justified those killings of those innocent, sleeping children by the South African military forces on the ground, that the house in question was an APLA base, do you know that?

Yes sir, I agree with that.  That is what made South African people who were here in the Transkei at the time, to be very angry that De Klerk allowed or De Klerk permitted orders to be given for such.

I see.  Now, I want you now to tell the Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel and everybody here, there you are in a moving funeral as you have indicated, what happened?  What happened then?

Sir, as you already said that we were members of the Self Defence Unit at the time, fighting against apartheid.  After the funeral, in great pain and grief, the comrades that were with as well, we drove off in a car.
Okay, then you drove off in a motor vehicle, where did you drive to and why did you drive there to?
And could we perhaps know the purpose of your going to Kokstad, why were you going to Kokstad?

The reason why we went to Kokstad sir, as such cruelty had taken place, especially towards the parents who lost their children, we went to Kokstad to show the then government that the pain that they caused us was not acceptable.
	At the time the police station of the government of the day, we took them as our targets.  Targets of the struggle.
	We wanted to humiliate the government of the day.

Okay, Mr Nyembezi, don't rush.  I've got problems keeping pace with you, just take your time, don't rush.
	You say you wanted to humiliate the government, which government did you want to humiliate and can you expantiate on this humiliation of the government?

De Klerk's government of oppression, who sent soldiers to cross the borders to come to the then Transkei because it was De Klerk's oppressive government that actually did this.
	That is why we wanted to humiliate them.
Can you explain what you mean by humiliation?

We wanted to show the government that their security system was weak, we were undermining their security system.  We wanted to show them that they couldn't just act any how towards the people any time they wanted.
Now, did you amongst yourselves as comrades, take that decision to go and humiliate the government the way you have just explained?
Now, where were you at the time you took this decision and when?
We were all students in Durban.
I haven't asked you that Mr Nyembezi.  My question is where were you at the time you took this decision and when was that?
We were in Umtata sir, after we had left the funeral.
I see.  By the way the funeral was conducted here in Umtata?
Tell me something Mr Nyembezi, for interest sake ...
You say we were in Umtata and this decision was taken after the funeral.  Who is we?
Solomzi Nomatshizolo, Luzuko Mpiyakhe, Luyanda Ntikinca.
What you say in the papers that you decided to retaliate, did you discuss what this retaliation would entail?

It was not attacking as such, however it was to show the government of the day in South Africa, that what they did was shameful.  At the time there were negotiations at the World Trade Centre.
	Fortunately those negotiations were handled by the ANC.  De Klerk did that to undermine the negotiations that led us to the democracy that we have today.

What I want to know, this application is about amnesty for the killing of policemen.
	When was that decision taken to kill the policemen?

I want to rectify something, the decision was not to go and kill policemen.  Our purpose was to humiliate the government of apartheid.
	I thought that I would get to the police matter later, when my Attorney asks me the question.

Thank you Honourable Mr Chair.  Now, there you are after this moving funeral, you are taking this decision look, let's go to Kokstad police station and our purpose should be that of humiliating the South African government, whatever.
Why did you have to go to Kokstad to do that?

As we took all police stations as our military targets, however it depends which one is more accessible to us according to our criteria as a soft target.
	Because we used to stay in Kokstad and we knew it well.
Oh, by the way, you say you knew Kokstad very well and you were all staying in Kokstad, that is why you picked on it?
The applicant did not respond to the question.
Is it correct that you found Kokstad to be the most accessible of all the soft targets, because you stayed there and you knew the area well?
That is correct sir, as I have already said.

Thank you Honourable Chair.  Now just one thing Mr Nyembezi, before we proceed further.
	The two policemen who are alleged to have been killed herein, Mr Mbhele and Mr Ngubo, did you know these two policemen generally?
No, I did not know them sir.
There is something which has been said by Counsel Brink to me, that you were in fact staying in the same street with Mr Mbhele.  What is your comment to that?
As I already said sir, I did not even know where Mr Mbhele stayed.
Now, when you went to this police station, did you know that at the police station, you would find in particular Mr Mbhele and Mr Ngubo?
No, we did not know that sir.
Did you perhaps, when you went there, know how many policemen you would find at the police station?

One of them sir, were two of our group Luzuko and Luyanda, had a surveillance to check how many people were there.  It is common knowledge that you would find two or three people there, however, there was a surveillance made.
I see.  Now, there you are, continue with your evidence, you are now at a stage where ...
Sorry, just a minute, when was the surveillance done?
Could the interpreter get clarification from the applicant?  The applicant said the same week as the funeral, not the week before the funeral, the interpreter apologises.
And what was the purpose of the surveillance at that stage, before the funeral?

I already said that what the government had done, the government wanted to demean the negotiations.  We took all police stations as our military targets, as SDU's.
	That was our political motive when we were in the struggle, fighting against oppression of the Boers.
That surveillance, did it take place before or after the funeral?
And had you been going to the home of the family in that week before the actual funeral?
Then I think we need clarity, did the surveillance take place before or after the actual killing of the children?
Sir, everything happened after the tragedy.
The surveillance of that police station, did it occur as a result of a decision by you four?
Where were you when that decision was taken?
We were at school sir, as I said.  We endorsed the decision even on the day of the funeral.
Where is that school where you were at?

Thank you Honourable Chair.  Mr Nyembezi, I think this needs some more clarification on your side, the surveillance and the decision taken.
	You had said to me you took the decision after the funeral, here in Umtata if I am not making a mistake, but I think you have just now said the Umtata thing, the Umtata decision taken was the endorsement of the decision you had taken before.  Could you clarify this because, and listen to the question and answer the question and think, listen properly.  Could you clarify this so that it be clear, because it is also not clear to me.  Could you clarify this point?
Sir, I said that this decision was motivated, it is the funeral that triggered such a decision for our people to be killed in such a brutal manner, by De Klerk's government.
How could the funeral have triggered that off when in fact the decision to survey the police station and embarrass the government of the time, had been taken in Durban before the funeral?

I did not say so sir, that we took the decision in Durban.
	I did not say that.
I understood that, and if I am wrong, then tell me what happened at Technikon at Durban?
The decision sir, was taken on the day that we left Durban to go to the funeral.
Just stop there, what exactly was that decision?  Maybe that is where some of the confusion is.

Honourable Committee, as I said the government wanted to demean or stagger the process of negotiations.  As the SDU we were protecting the South African community, whoever it was, the oppressed.
	The soldiers at the time, that is what made us decide and we made that decision as we went to the funeral.
You still haven't answered the question, what was the decision taken at Durban?
We decided that as the members of the SDU, to humiliate the government of the day, to show them that what they did to us, was painful, to kill our people.
Now, at that time, did you decide what that humiliation would entail?

We said that we must go to our targets in humiliation of the government of the day, as it was any police station then, was a target of the liberation movement.
	We took that decision that Kokstad was our soft target as a police station.  We then decided to go and humiliate the government there with the deed that we were going to commit there.
	We were going to get there, take the police and their weapons.  Our purpose was to just leave these policemen in some obscure place because these were the people that the system trusted, they were their pillars of oppression and they were protecting the government of the day.  We wanted to demonstrate to the government how weak their security system was.

Thank you Honourable Chair.  Mr Nyembezi,  we are now, listen to me carefully and answer the question, we are now at a stage where you say you have taken the decision to humiliate the government.
	You have already mentioned, I must be corrected on that, you wanted to take the police and leave them at a far away place.  When you went to the said police station, how many of you had firearms?
Thank you very much, and who was that?
I see.  Now, the other three of you ...
Are you saying there was only one firearm between the four of you?
Thank you Honourable Chair.  The other three, that is you and the other two, what did you have with you?  What were you carrying?
I see.  Now, did Mr Nomatshizolo fire with that firearm at the police station in Bongweni, Kokstad?
No, well at this police station, did any three of you who were armed with knives, stab or use those knives against any person, at the police station?
No sir, we did not stab anyone.
Now, to be clear on this, how many policemen did you find there, after you had entered?

I see.  We want now to have the picture Mr Nyembezi, of the police station in question.  What were these two policemen doing, I take it that there should a counter at the police station, blah, blah, blah, what were these two policemen doing at the time you entered the police station?

I am going to put it this way sir, when we got there and entered, as I said with Mr Nomatshizolo who was armed with a firearm, they first went in and then Ntikinca and Nyembezi went in after that.
	Mr Nomatshizolo would answer this question better than I, because he is the one who went in first.
Now, talk about the time you entered yourself.  At the time you entered, how were the two policemen positioned?
The one was behind the counter sir, and the other next to the heater, with their arms in the air.
Thank you Honourable Chair.  You have talked about arms having held up, were they both holding up their arms, the two policemen?

Thank you Honourable Chair, thank you Mr Chair.  Now, in paragraph 16 of your affidavit you have said we went in,  found two policemen, and we indicated to them that it was not our intention to kill them.  We further advised them that we were going to take them, go away with them and dump them far away from the police station.
	Who actually said this?
All of us sir, I also said.   I tried to assure them that what we were saying was true, and they had believed it as well sir.
Now, whilst you were taking the two policemen, did they in any way show any kind of resistance or did they cooperate with you after you told them this?

In the way we explained to them sir, they cooperated.   They didn't show any resistance.
	It seemed as if they trusted us.
I see.  Now, we understand, I understand there are also firearms that were taken from the police station in question, on the day in question.  Is that so?
Can you tell us about the taking of firearms, what can you say about the taking of firearms?  How did that occur?

It happened in this way, when we were inside and they held their arms up high, they said we must not kill them and they showed us where the guns were stocked and told us how we could get those firearms.  We told them, yes, we are going to take those arms, and take them too and explained what our intentions were, simply to insult and humiliate the government, nothing more.

I see.  Don't be fast Mr Nyembezi, please.  You are very, very fast.
	Thank you Honourable Chair.  Now, you took them, the police and the firearms, then you got them in the vehicle in which you were driving?
Did you in any way have these two policemen tied?
We did not tie them in any fashion, we just left them like that.
Now, in the vehicle in which you were driving these policemen, can you tell the Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel, how you were in fact seated?
Luyanda and myself, we were in the front of the car.  Luzuko and Solomzi were at the back.  It was a panel van sir.
And the firearms you had taken from the police station, where did you put them?  Did you put them in the cab with you or did you put them in the bakkie with Luyanda and Solomzi?
The guns sir and the police, Luzuko and Solomzi were at the back, on the floor.
We continued sir, going towards Umtata.  We then branched off towards Bizana. We just wanted to take them far off in an obscure place where it would be difficult for them to go back home.
As we were driving sir, our car started jerking whilst we were going towards Bizana.
We were still trying to figure what it was with the car, we sort of sensed that the car was jerking even more.
As we were sitting there in front of the car, we heard a sound, a gunshot.
I see.  Now you heard a gunshot.  And then, what happened?  Were you by this time still in the cab of the vehicle in question, that is yourself and Luyanda?
Yes sir.  We were so shocked and surprised.  We stopped the car right there and then, took cover because we didn't know what was happening.
I see, who was actually driving the motor vehicle in question?

I see, Luyanda was driving.  Now, there you are, the jerking of the vehicle, there is gunshot, firing of a gun, then you said you took cover.
	What do you mean by that, did you come out of the vehicle Luyanda was driving, or this cover you are talking about, did you take it inside the cab?
After the jerking, and the gunshot, we stopped the car and took cover.

Mr Nyembezi, you have not as yet answered my question.  Listen to me and answer my question.  I am saying you, listen to my question, I am saying the cover you are talking about, we are in a situation, our picture now is you and Luyanda being in the cab of the vehicle, Luyanda driving, and we are in a position now, situation where the vehicle in question is apparently giving problems.  My question to you is simple, you also mention that you took cover.
	My question is simple, did you take this cover while still in the bakkie, that is in the cab, or did you alight from the vehicle in question, simple?
We stopped the car first, after the car had stopped, there was a gunshot.  Luyanda and I got out of the car and took cover.
I see.  Then what happened thereafter, there you are, you have gone out, you are taking cover, what happened?  You are now out of the vehicle with Luyanda, what happened?
After we took cover, we saw the police that were supposed to be in the car, outside shooting.
I see.  Now where was Luzuko and Solomzi, that is the two who had been in the bakkie of the panel van in question?
Unfortunately Luzuko is the person who got shot.  Solomzi ran away and took cover.
My question to you Mr Nyembezi has been where was Luzuko and Solomzi at the time you came out of the vehicle and tried to take cover, answer the question please.
They were inside sir, because we were the first ones to get out and take cover.
Are you saying mr Nyembezi, at the time you came out of the vehicle, from the cab where you were seated with Luyanda, Luzuko and Solomzi were still inside the vehicle in question, in the bakkie?
Yes sir, that is what I am saying, because the sound was from behind us.
I see, okay proceed.  Tell the Honourable Chair and Honourable members of the Panel and everybody here, what happened thereafter?

After that sir, as I have already said, the police started shooting.
	They were shooting and they were trying to run away.
I see.  Whom were the police shooting, at whom were the firing of the police directed?
What did you do, there are the policemen running, shooting at you.  What did you do?
The interpreter did not understand the applicant.
We started to shoot back at them.
I see.  You have mentioned something of it being dark.
Yes, I did say so sir.

Now, can you know Mr Nyembezi, how many, oh before I go to that Honourable Chair, sorry sir, with what were you in particular firing with?   Because we know you as a person who had been in fact armed with a knife at the time you went to this police station.  With what were you now shooting?
The police gun sir, that were taken from the police.  I had a 9 mm.
I see.  Did your co-knife holder comrades, also take firearms like you had taken, 9 mm pistols?
Yes sir, both Luyanda and I had 9 mm's.
I see.  Now, did you Mr Nyembezi and your comrades give chase to these two policemen because you have mentioned something of running away?
Yes sir.  We were shooting, following them.
I see.  Can you perhaps be in a position to tell the distance you took, chasing them?
It was about 55 metres sir, about 55 metres.
Now, did you - who actually gave chase of the four of you?
It was myself, Solomzi and Luyanda sir.
Luzuko was inside the car, laying there.
As you were chasing the two policemen, did you had the occasion of actually arriving at them, as you were chasing them, firing at them, did you have the occasion of actually arriving at them?
I see.   Now, what made you to stop firing?
We heard that there was silence from their side, sir.
Did you ever go to check whether these two policemen had been hit or otherwise?
No sir, we didn't go and ascertain that.
Now, you then came back to your motor vehicle.
You have mentioned Luzuko having been injured, what had injured Luzuko and how was he injured?
It was the gunshots sir, that had gotten in the hand.
I see.  Now what did you do thereafter, tell the Honourable Chair and members of the Panel.
We were shocked, we rushed him off, we did not use the same route.  We went to join the N2 towards Umtata.
Then you go to Umtata and what happened after you had gone to Umtata?
We went to the St Mary's hospital.
That is taking Luzuko to be attended, medically attended?
I see.  Is that all Mr Nyembezi?
That is not all sir.  I left Solomzi and Luyanda attending to Luzuko at the hospital.  I drove ...
I left Luzuko and Luyanda, the car that we were in, had bullet shots in it, marks.  Can I carry on sir?
Where did you go to Mr Nyembezi, where did you go to sir?
I left in that car sir.  I tried to get a phone.
Whom were you phoning Mr Nyembezi?
I was phoning Ntsiki, comrade Ntsiki.
I see.   Now, who is comrade Ntsiki?
One of the Commanders that I had been introduced to by comrade Matshaya.
I see.  Now, who had actually trained you was it Matshaya?
I see.   Now did you get hold of comrade Ntsiki and did he come?
I found comrade Ntsiki sir, he did come.
What was the purpose of you contacting this comrade Ntsiki?

The reason why I got in touch with Ntsiki, is because I wanted him to keep the guns that we had confiscated from the police.
	There was still a problem, we had to attend to comrade Luzuko.
Did he then take the firearms in question, that is comrade Ntsiki?
No, not all of them sir.
Now, can you tell how many firearms he left with you and the types of those firearms?
Two guns, a shotgun and a rifle, R1 rifle.
Sorry, what about these two guns?
These are guns that Ntsiki left with me.
Just describe those if you can?
Did the two policemen you were shooting at, get away with any guns?

Thank you very much, thank you.  Now, we are now at a stage where you say you handed over all the firearms to Ntsiki and you took with you two firearms, an R1 and a shotgun.
	What eventually happened to that R1 and the shotgun?
I gave them to Luyanda, Mr Ntikinca sir.

I see.  Now, lastly Mr Nyembezi, I am about to finish Honourable Chair, we are here as I have already said to you before, and you are here with the families of the people who have in fact died.
	What can you say about the death of those two policemen and what can you also say to the families of the deceased herein?

Sir, to the families who lost their people, their grief and our grief, as it was not out intention to kill.  We have come here, forward, to reconcile.
	We ask for forgiveness, we all say and I say to the families...

Lastly, the Committee, the Honourable Committee here, we pray that as our intentions or as our deeds were politically motivated, we have come here to tell the truth as to what happened.  We hope that we get amnesty therefore.
	This sir, is from the bottom of our hearts.
Thank you very much Mr Nyembezi, thank you very much Honourable Chair, that is the evidence of Mr Nyembezi sir.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR NOTUNUNU

Mr Nyembezi, I just want to clarify one or two things with you.
	From what you tell us, and how you shot and when you stopped, I see you have made application for amnesty in respect of the death of those policemen, not so, or a policeman?

I see in, when you read your initial application, and the one submitted by your Attorney, that amongst other things you made application for amnesty in respect of the death of this policeman, correct?

From what you had testified today, you say that you shot at these people when they were escaping and when they stopped shooting, you turned around and went back to your motor vehicle, do you recall saying so?
From what I understand of your evidence, you are not too sure if you caused the death of that policeman or am I wrong?
As I understand your evidence this morning, you are not in a position to say whether the policemen died as a result of your shooting?  Do you understand that?
Sorry Judge, do you refer to him as a person or to them as a group?
And let's talk about the collective actions.  Are you in a position to say that the actions of perhaps your colleagues, caused the death of the policemen?
If I understand your question well, it seems as if you are asking me if it is my comrades that caused the death of the police, if you could repeat your question please.
What I am asking you is whether you can say yourself, that this policemen died as a result of the actions of your colleagues?
That the police died as a result of my comrades, including myself?
Yes, let's put it that way?
Why do you say that is so?
Are you saying that you are accepting responsibility for the death of that policeman because of what you described here to us this morning?
I am trying to understand the question well.  Are you asking me if I am the only one who takes responsibility for the police having been killed?

I don't know why you have difficulty with the question.  The question is simple, in your activities that night, there was an operation in progress, there were four of you.  All I am asking is, did this policemen die as a result of what you and your colleagues did during that operation that night?
Because sir, I was also one of the people who shot and killed the policemen.
How do you know that the policemen died as a result of any of the shots fired by you or your colleagues?
The interpreter is just repeating the question to the witness.
We got a report from newspapers that the police had died.
How did you know it was the same policemen that you had fired at that was referred to in the newspaper?
The newspapers stipulated that these policemen were taken from the offices in Bongweni.
Did it not tell you, or did it not say in the report that the bodies of these policemen were found at a particular place?
The route to Bizana, towards Bruce Neck.
Was that a place in the vicinity of which you shot at these policemen?
Did you know the identity of these policemen?
I did not know them sir.
All you know is that the policemen were abducted from the police station near Kokstad, were found dead in the vicinity where you and your colleagues had shot at two policemen?
Did you read the application of Solomzi?

See, it can't be held against you, but I just want to clarify one point that they say in their application.
	On pages 51 and 58 of this bundle, I just want to read what both of them say because it is the same wording in both.
	They then ran away, we started firing to their direction, following them.  We cornered them, or we cornered and shot them but at a different location.  
	Do you understand what they say?
As I see it being written sir.
No, I am not asking whether you see it written, I am asking whether you understand what I have just read out to you?
Now, would you agree there seems to be a bit of difference between your version and what they write down in their application?  Would you agree?
All I want to ask you is, have you any comments about that?
I could say sir, in the chaos there was confusion in the shootings, perhaps they had forgotten some things when they were writing the application.
I must point out that when they used the word we, it does not necessarily include you.

Mr Chairman and Honourable members of the Panel, before I begin, my learned friend Mr Notununu indicated to me during the tea adjournment, that he had a couple of more questions to put to the applicant.

Thank you Honourable Chair, may I first of all put my name clear, Notununu, Notununu, not Notunu, thank you very much.
	Honourable Chair, after we had adjourned, at the time of our adjournment, some documents were in fact handed over to Mr Brink by the Kokstad Station Commander.  I had in fact, if I may mention that in the morning I had in fact asked Mr Brink whether there are any documents which he intends using in this Commission and he had indicated that there are none.
